#Text=HEARTS AND OTHER HEARTS

#Text=Stephen had brought a change of clothes , as he had a habit of being ducked once at least during the day ; and since there was a halt in the proceedings and no need of his services for an hour or two , he found Rose and walked with her to a secluded spot where they could watch the logs and not be seen by the people .
#Text="

#Text=You frightened everybody almost to death , jumping into the river ,  chided Rose .

#Text= They thought I was a fool to save a fool , I suppose . "

column1: #Text=" Perhaps not as bad as that , but it did seem reckless . "
#Text=" I know ; and the boy , no doubt , would be better off dead ; but so should I be , if I could have let him die . "
#Text=Rose regarded this strange point of view for a moment , and then silently acquiesced in it .
#Text=She was constantly doing this , and she often felt that her mental horizon broadened in the act ; but she could not be sure that Stephen grew any dearer to her because of his moral altitudes .
#Text=" Besides , " Stephen argued , " I happened to be nearest to the river , and it was my job . "
#Text=" How do you always happen to be nearest to the people in trouble , and why is it always your ' job ' ! "
#Text=" If there are any rewards for good conduct being distributed , I 'm right in line with my hand stretched out , " Stephen replied , with meaning in his voice .
#Text=Rose blushed under her flowery hat as he led the way to a bench under a sycamore tree that overhung the water .
#Text=She had almost convinced herself that she was as much in love with Stephen Waterman as it was in her nature to be with anybody .
#Text=He was handsome in his big way , kind , generous , temperate , well educated , and well-to-do .
#Text=No fault could be found with his family , for his mother had been a teacher , and his father , though a farmer , a college graduate .
#Text=Stephen himself had had one year at Bowdoin , but had been recalled , as the head of the house , when his father died .
#Text=That was a severe blow ; but his mother 's death , three years after , was a grief never to be quite forgotten .
#Text=Rose , too , was the child of a gently bred mother , and all her instincts were refined .

#Text=Yes ; Stephen in himself satisfied her in all the larger wants of her nature , but she had an unsatisfied hunger for the world , -- the world of Portland , where her cousins lived ; or , better still , the world of Boston , of which she heard through Mrs. Wealthy Brooks , whose nephew Claude often came to visit her in Edgewood .

#Text=Life on a farm a mile and a half distant from post-office and stores ; life in the house with Rufus , who was rumored to be somewhat wild and unsteady , -- this prospect seemed a trifle dull and uneventful to the trivial part of her , though to the better part it was enough .
#Text=The better part of her loved Stephen Waterman , dimly feeling the richness of his nature , the tenderness of his affection , the strength of his character .
#Text=Rose was not destitute either of imagination or sentiment .
#Text=She did not relish this constant weighing of Stephen in the balance : he was too good to be weighed and considered .

#Text=She longed to be carried out of herself on a wave of rapturous assent , but something seemed to hold her back , -- some seed of discontent with the man 's environment and circumstances , some germ of longing for a gayer , brighter , more varied life .
#Text=No amount of self-searching or argument could change the situation .

#Text=She always loved Stephen more or less : more when he was away from her , because she never approved his collars nor the set of his shirt bosom ; and as he naturally wore these despised articles of apparel whenever he proposed to her , she was always lukewarm about marrying him and settling down on the River Farm .
#Text=Still , to-day she discovered in herself , with positive gratitude , a warmer feeling for him than she had experienced before .
#Text=He wore a new and becoming gray flannel shirt , with the soft turnover collar that belonged to it , and a blue tie , the color of his kind eyes .

#Text=She knew that he had shaved his beard at her request not long ago , and that when she did not like the effect as much as she had hoped , he had meekly grown a mustache for her sake ; it did seem as if a man could hardly do more to please an exacting lady-love .
#Text=And she had admired him unreservedly when he pulled off his boots and jumped into the river to save Alcestis Crambry 's life , without giving a single thought to his own .
#Text=And was there ever , after all , such a noble , devoted , unselfish fellow , or a better brother ?
#Text=And would she not despise herself for rejecting him simply because he was countrified , and because she longed to see the world of the fashion-plates in the magazines ?
#Text=" The logs are so like people ! " she exclaimed , as they sat down .
#Text=" I could name nearly every one of them for somebody in the village .

#Text=Look at Mite Shapley , that dancing little one , slipping over the falls and skimming along the top of the water , keeping out of all the deep places , and never once touching the rocks .
